name: TOI-700
scenarioDescription:
The TOI-700 Exoplanetary System

TOI-700 is a star with 0.41 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.42 times its radius. It is located 101.34 light years away from the solar system.

TOI-700 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

TOI-700 b

TOI-700 b was discovered by the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2020-07. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 9.98 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, TOI-700.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.081, which means that when TOI-700 b is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.06 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 0.07. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of TOI-700 b is 1.06 times the mass of Earth. The radius of TOI-700 b is 1.037 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, TOI-700 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

TOI-700 c

TOI-700 c was discovered by the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2020-07. Its semi-major axis is 0.09 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 16.05 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, TOI-700.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.078, which means that when TOI-700 c is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.09 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 0.10. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of TOI-700 c is 9.93 times the mass of Earth. The radius of TOI-700 c is 2.65 that of Earth. At 9.93 Earth masses, TOI-700 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

TOI-700 d

TOI-700 d was discovered by the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2020-07. Its semi-major axis is 0.16 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 37.42 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, TOI-700.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.111, which means that when TOI-700 d is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.15 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 0.18. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of TOI-700 d is 1.33 times the mass of Earth. The radius of TOI-700 d is 1.144 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, TOI-700 d is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

With a semi-major axis of 0.1633 astronomical units, and a mass of 1.33 Earth masses, TOI-700 d could, potentially, be a habitable planet with stable bodies of liquid water on its surface, like Earth.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system TOI-700, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS).
